text:
Surgeons hardly use
the scalpel anymore.

Almost all the cutting that
is performed during surgery

is done using an
electric cautery

pencil, a device
with a metal tip

that cuts by delivering
electricity to tissue.

But surgeons face a
big problem every day
when they use this device.

Imagine you're a surgeon
trying to operate

with your pencil
in a small opening.

As you're cutting, blood
starts building up in the wound

and suddenly you can't
see what you're cutting.

You're forced to
drop the pencil,

pick up a suction tube
to clear the fluid,
and switch back to the pencil.

But you've been on
your feet for hours

and you're irritated
from constantly

having to switch back and
forth between the suction
and the pencil.

You decide just to let
the fluid accumulate,

you try and cut what
you can't see, and boom,

you cut something
you wish you hadn't.

My co-founder Dr. Kim and
I met in the operating room

when we were in a situation
just like the one I described.

Together we were
inspired to invent
a device that changes the game.

It's the clear cut
electric cautery pencil.

It's a standard pencil
when you need it to be

and it transforms instantly
into a suction device
at the click of a button.

Surgeons can effortlessly
alternate between these two

functionalities and
take complete control
over their surgical environment.
Imagine you're the patient.

Would you want a frustrated
surgeon operating on you?
I certainly wouldn't.

ClearCut has set
out to transform

surgeon-centered innovation
and give patients
the care they deserve.
